Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the father needs to respond
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The weekly study circle meets tonight to discuss a chapter they have not yet reviewed.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the school’s email open on my phone, my heart pounding. My son had been caught bullying a classmate. The principal wanted me to come in tonight to discuss what happened. As a father, I knew I needed to be there for my child, to show him right from wrong, to support and guide him through this mistake. But tonight was also the weekly Buddhist study circle, a time I cherished for reflection and spiritual growth. We were set to discuss a chapter I hadn’t yet read, and I felt a responsibility to my sangha, to my own practice, to show up and learn together. The two worlds pulled at me—one demanding my presence as a parent, the other calling me to deepen my understanding and compassion. I felt torn, guilt rising no matter which way I leaned. My son needed me, but so did my own spiritual path. I stared at the clock, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which part of myself to honor tonight.
